queue.php

00001 <table class="manual" id="basic">
00002   <caption>queueing</caption>
00003   <tr>
00004     <th>Statement</th>
00005     <th>Description</th>
00006   </tr>
00007   <tr>
00008     <td colspan="2">
00009         Once interfaces are activated for queueing using the altq directive, a
00010         sequence of queue directives may be defined.  The name associated with a
00011         queue must match a queue defined in the altq directive (e.g. mail), or,
00012         except for the priq scheduler, in a parent queue declaration.  The following 
00013         keywords can be used:
00014     </td>
00015   </tr>
00016   <tr>
00017     <td nowrap="nowrap">on <strong>interface</strong></td>
00018     <td>Specifies the interface the queue operates on.  If not given, it
00019         operates on all matching interfaces.
00020     </td>
00021   </tr>
00022   <tr>
00023     <td nowrap="nowrap">bandwidth <strong>bw</strong></td>
00024     <td>Specifies the maximum bitrate to be processed by the queue.  This
00025         value must not exceed the value of the parent queue and can be
00026         specified as an absolute value or a percentage of the parent
00027         queue's bandwidth.  The priq scheduler does not support bandwidth
00028         specification.
00029     </td>
00030   </tr>
00031   <tr>
00032     <td nowrap="nowrap">priority <strong>level</strong></td>
00033     <td>Between queues a priority level can be set.  For cbq and hfsc, the
00034         range is 0 to 7 and for priq, the range is 0 to 15.  The default
00035         for all is 1.  Priq queues with a higher priority are always served
00036         first.  Cbq and Hfsc queues with a higher priority are preferred in
00037         the case of overload.
00038     </td>
00039   </tr>
00040   <tr>
00041     <td nowrap="nowrap">qlimit <strong>limit</strong></td>
00042     <td>The maximum number of packets held in the queue. The default is 50.</td>
00043   </tr>
00044   <tr>
00045     <td colspan="2">
00046       <p>The scheduler can get additional parameters with <strong>scheduler</strong>(
00047         <strong>parameters</strong> ).  Parameters are as follows:</p>
00048 
00049       <table>
00050         <tr>
00051           <td class="key">default</td>
00052           <td>Packets not matched by another queue are assigned to this
00053               one.  Exactly one default queue is required.
00054           </td>
00055         </tr>
00056         <tr>
00057           <td class="key">red</td>
00058           <td>Enable RED (Random Early Detection) on this queue.  RED drops
00059               packets with a probability proportional to the average queue
00060               length.
00061           </td>
00062         </tr>
00063         <tr>
00064           <td class="key">rio</td>
00065           <td>Enables RIO on this queue.  RIO is RED with IN/OUT, thus running 
00066               RED two times more than RIO would achieve the same effect.
00067               RIO is currently not supported in the GENERIC kernel.
00068           </td>
00069         </tr>
00070         <tr>
00071           <td class="key">ecn</td>
00072           <td>Enables ECN (Explicit Congestion Notification) on this queue.
00073               ECN implies RED.
00074           </td>
00075         </tr>
00076       </table>
00077     </td>
00078   </tr>
00079 
00080   <tr>
00081     <td colspan="2">
00082       <p>The cbq scheduler supports an additional option:</p>
00083       
00084       <table>
00085         <tr>
00086           <td class="key">borrow</td>
00087           <td>The queue can borrow bandwidth from the parent.</td>
00088         </tr>
00089       </table>
00090       
00091       <p>The hfsc scheduler supports some additional options:</p>
00092       
00093       <table>
00094         <tr>
00095           <td class="key">realtime <strong>sc</strong></td>
00096           <td>The minimum required bandwidth for the queue.</td>
00097         </tr>
00098         <tr>
00099           <td class="key">upperlimit <strong>sc</strong></td>
00100           <td>The maximum allowed bandwidth for the queue.</td>
00101         </tr>
00102         <tr>
00103           <td class="key">linkshare <strong>sc</strong></td>
00104           <td>The bandwidth share of a backlogged queue.</td>
00105         </tr>
00106       </table>
00107       
00108       <p>&lt;sc&gt; is an acronym for service curve.</p>
00109 
00110       <p>The format for service curve specifications is (m1, d, m2).  m2 controls
00111          the bandwidth assigned to the queue.  m1 and d are optional and can be
00112          used to control the initial bandwidth assignment.  For the first d 
00113          milliseconds the queue gets the bandwidth given as m1, afterwards the value
00114          given in m2.</p>
00115 
00116       <p>Furthermore, with cbq and hfsc, child queues can be specified as in an
00117          altq declaration, thus building a tree of queues using a part of their
00118          parent's bandwidth.</p>
00119 
00120       <p>Packets can be assigned to queues based on filter rules by using the
00121          queue keyword.  Normally only one queue is specified; when a second one
00122          is specified it will instead be used for packets which have a TOS of
00123          lowdelay and for TCP ACKs with no data payload.</p>
00124 
00125       <p>To continue the previous example, the examples below would specify the
00126          four referenced queues, plus a few child queues.  Interactive ssh(1) sessions 
00127          get priority over bulk transfers like scp(1) and sftp(1).  The
00128          queues may then be referenced by filtering rules.</p>
00129 
00130 <pre>
00131 queue std bandwidth 10% cbq(default)
00132 queue http bandwidth 60% priority 2 cbq(borrow red) { employees, developers }
00133 queue   developers bandwidth 75% cbq(borrow)
00134 queue   employees bandwidth 15%
00135 queue mail bandwidth 10% priority 0 cbq(borrow ecn)
00136 queue ssh bandwidth 20% cbq(borrow) { ssh_interactive, ssh_bulk }
00137 queue   ssh_interactive priority 7
00138 queue   ssh_bulk priority 0
00139 
00140 block return out on dc0 inet all queue std
00141 pass out on dc0 inet proto tcp from $developerhosts to any port 80 keep state queue developers
00142 pass out on dc0 inet proto tcp from $employeehosts to any port 80 keep state queue employees
00143 pass out on dc0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 22 keep state queue(ssh_bulk, ssh_interactive)
00144 pass out on dc0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 25 keep state queue mail
00145 </pre>
00146     </td>
00147   </tr>
00148 </table>
